metadata.title: Microwave-assisted preparation of Nano-hydroxyapatite for bone substitutes

sections.text:
http://dx.doi.org/ 0272-8842/& 20
nCorrespondin Helmholtz-Platz
E-mail addre
Please cite this //dx.doi.org/10
Calcium phosphate-based biomaterials have been frequently used as bone substitutes and osteoconductive scaffolds due to their chemical similarity to the inorganic phase of bone. Hydroxyapatite (HA) is the most frequently used calcium phosphate-based biomaterials and it could be prepared from natural or synthesized sources via several processes. Nano-HA (nHA) particles were suggested to have superior bioresorbtion and close chemical and crystallographic structure to natural bone apatite. Currently, microwave-assisted (MW) processing of biomaterials, particularly bioceramics, has more appealing advantages than conventional heating methods. It works through an internally generated heat inside the materials molecules instead of originating external heating source and subsequent radiative transfer as in the conventional heating. Thus, MW synthesis of HA offers several benefits including rapid heating, shorter synthesis time, efficient energy transformation and throughout volume heating. The purpose of this review is to highlight the various methods and the paradigm shift of MW techniques to synthesize nHA in the past 25 years. Peer-reviewed journal publications (Scopus and Google Scholar indexed articles) in which titles and keywords combining “Microwave AND Nano-Hydroxyapatite” were collected from 1990 till May 2015. The discussions include the state-of-the-art and the role of reaction parameters on the HA structures, size, morphology and biocompatibility to be further used for bone regeneration applications. & 2015 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Microwave processing; Bone substitutes; Calcium phosphates; Nano-hydroxyapatite.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Biomaterials play a pivotal role as scaffolds to provide three-dimensional templates and synthetic extracellular matrix (ECM) environments for tissue regeneration and drug delivery [1]. In theory, biomaterials have to imitate the properties of the host tissues and support essential cell functions while avoiding toxic reactions and advert immune responses [2]. Bone tissue replacement graft/scaffold(s) could be polymers, ceramics, metals or composites (Fig. 1). Bioceramics, particularly calcium phosphate (CaP) based biomaterials, have frequently been used as bone substitutes and osteoconductive scaffolds due to their chemical similarity to the inorganic phase of bone [3]. Currently, CaP biomaterials are widely used to promote bone regeneration instead of autogenous bone graft transplantation for orthopedics, oral and maxillofacial bone defects [4], in addition to implant coatings [5] or bone substitute filler [6].
CaP family includes four main categories: Hydroxyapatite (HA) with Ca/P ratio equal 1.67, calcium deficient Hydroxyapatite (CDHA) (tetracalcium phosphate or octacalcium
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
phosphate), Tricalcium Phosphates (α or β-TCP), and Biphasic Calcium Phosphate (BCP) with less Ca/P ratio [7]. When precipitating CaP in basic aqueous solutions, three main different solid phases could be formed: either amorphous calcium phosphates (ACP), Octate calcium phosphates (OCP) or HA. These phases are ascending in their thermodynamic order and descending on the time scale [8,9]. Although being similar chemically, their crystal, mechanical, physical and biological properties differ according to the processing parameters (temperature, pH, feed ratio, partial pressure of water, aging time and the presence of impurities)

[10]. Accordingly, their rate of biodegradation also varies in the following order: OCP4α-TCP4β-TCP4HA [7]. Among different forms of CaP, most attention has been paid to β-TCP (Ca3(PO4)2) and HA (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2) (Fig. 2) due to their outstanding biological responses to the physiological environment [11].
Various methods were used to prepare HA in different forms and sizes in the past decades [9]. Microwave (MW)-assisted preparation of Nano-HA (nHA) could be considered as a new processing and heat treatment technique that was added to various HA used preparation methods (Fig. 3). Many reviews were published to survey the MW synthesis of many types of Nano-materials including metallic, inorganic, polymeric nanostructures and their composites [12–15]. On the other hand, the recently published reviews on the various methods of nHA
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
synthesis had discussed MW-assisted methods in brief, as a synergetic synthesis strategy [9,16,17]. MW-assisted preparation of nHA was found to be significantly efficient and economic [17–20]. Hence, a growing interest in MW-assisted processing of biomaterials is developing and expanding [21]. Here, we will focus only on the MWassisted processes that have reported the synthesis of pure HA in the Nano-scale for the last 25 years (from 1990 to May 2015) (Table 1). Doped HA or MW prepared HA in larger particle sizes or with other phases was excluded from this review. MW-assisted sintering of nHA was also excluded. The validation of the proposed HA precipitation mechanism was inspected compared to the HA precipitation using conventional heating. The aim of the study is to better understand if there is any difference between the action mechanism between

sections.heading: 2. MW-assisted nano-HA for bone regeneration and drug delivery
sections.text:
In general CaP, especially HA and TCP, have attracted interest as bone substitutes [22–24], drug delivery vehicles [25,26] and protein carriers [27,28]. Since 1990, different forms of HA biomaterials have shown osteoinductivity, together with long-term sustainability and size stability of the neo-bone [24]. Nano-structured HA can be tailored to obtain desired chemical compositions, surface properties (specifically topography), mechanical properties and distribution of grain size similar to those of physiological bone (which contains 70% by weight of HA ceramic with grain sizes less than 100 nm) [29].
Nano-hydroxyapatite (nHA) particles per se were expected to have superior bioresorbtion and close chemical and crystallographic structure with natural bone apatite [30]. Moreover, nHA have been used in different composites to promote osteoblast (bone forming cells) adhesion [31], migration and differentiation [32] for potential applications in bone engineering [33] with good biocompatibility [34,35], osteogenesis [36] and angiogenesis [37].
nHA could be prepared from natural sources [38], meanwhile several synthesis processes were developed to produce synthetic nHA which include wet chemical routes of precipitation [10,39], hydrothermal methods [40,41], plasma spraying [42], high-temperature solid-state reactions [43], sol–gel methods [44,45], polymeric precursor route [46], micro emulsion techniques [47] and MW-assisted synthesis [48].
MW-assisted synthesized HA was approved for its cell biocompatibility [49], and the ability of bioresorbtion in stimulated body fluid with a dissolution rate fairly higher than
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
conventional HA and closer to biological apatite due to its nano-structure processing [30]. Huang et al., investigated the effects of micro-sized MW synthesized HA (μHA) versus Nano-sized conventionally precipitated HA (nHA) on the osteogenic differentiation of rat bone marrow derived mesenchymal stem cells (rBMSCs) [32]. It was shown that the cells expressed higher levels of osteoblast-related markers with nHA than μ-HA stimulation. The results indicated also that the size of HA is an important factor for affecting the osteogenic differentiation of rBMSCs and provided a new approach to study stem cell differentiation and to obtain more committed differentiated cells. For the purpose of drug delivery, MW was used to prepare nHA in the form of self-assembled hollow structures and was applied in various studies of drug delivery [50–52]. In 2013, Qi et al. has prepared porous, amorphous CaP Nano-spheres [53] and nHA [54] via MW-assisted hydrothermal synthesis. The synthesized Nano-porous structures showed high efficiency in drug-loading/release in addition to their proteinadsorption capacities. Most recently, MW-assisted synthesized nHA was prepared as a monophase and compared to its Nanocomposite with alumina for orthopedic applications. The nHA monophase showed better hemocompatibility (red blood cells lysis) than its Nano-composite with alumina [55].

sections.heading: 3. Microwave processing of materials
sections.text:
Microwaves (frequencies of 300 MHz–300 GHz with wavelengths of 1 m–1 mm) lie between radio waves and infrared frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum (Fig. 4a). The most effective way to produce MW is from a magnetron source, but they can also be produced from klystrons, power grid tubes, traveling wave tubes and gyrotrons [56]. MW can be reflected, transmitted and/or absorbed when applied on a particular material. The absorbed MW energy is converted into heat within the material, resulting in an increase in temperature. Indeed, gases, liquids and solids can interact with MW to be heated. Under certain conditions, gases can be excited by MW to form plasmas that also can be useful for processing [57]. In many cases, materials processing using MW technology have numerous advantages compared to traditional materials processing techniques. These anticipated benefits include more precise and controlled volumetric heating, faster ramp-up to temperature, lower energy consumption, and enhanced quality and properties of the processed materials [58,59]. In addition, MW is convenient and economic method thus expected to be optimized for mass production [19,60] although the known limitations of penetration depth of MW [13]. Hence, MW assisted materials synthesis has become an appealing synthetic tool, even though the use of MW radiation in biomaterials science is still limited, with an apparent growing interest to be used in biomaterials synthesis for the next decade [21]. A basic understanding of MW and their interaction with materials is required to gain the advantages and to know the limitations of MW processing. M.N. Hassan et al. / Ceramics International ] (]]]]) ]]]–]]]10
then conducted from the hot surface to the relatively cold interior until finally a uniform temperature is reached throughout. Thus, it can take a long time for the middle of the material to become hot. Heat is conducted to the interior from the surface through the propagation of anharmonic elastic waves (phonon conductivity), while at elevated temperatures (4600 1C) the materials emit high frequency electromagnetic radiation (photon conductivity). So the overall thermal conductivity will be a combination of phonons and photons [61].
On the other hand, MW processing could be more efficient than conventional thermal processing because the MW energy can be directly coupled with the material at the molecular level. Generally, the MW electric field polarizes the molecules, which may couple with the rapid reversal of the electric field (Fig. 4b). Such interaction results in the conversion of electromagnetic energy into heat within the irradiated material due to intermolecular friction [62,63]. The specific MW effect on the polar species include selective heating and super heating of these species in the reaction medium [15,64]. This should be followed by a heat transfer processes from the superheated zones (hot spots) to those with the lower temperature. This also could lead to the formation of novel phases and selective crystallization.
MW can be absorbed by materials either through polarization or conduction processes. Polarization involves short-range displacement of charge through formation and rotation of electric dipoles (or magnetic dipoles, if present). Conduction requires long-range (compared to rotation) transport of charge. Both processes give rise to absorption losses in certain frequency ranges (Fig. 5). The absorption losses (also referred to as dielectric losses), ε˝, are due to ionic conduction, dominant at low frequencies, and rotation of permanent dipoles at higher frequencies. Therefore, the electric field generated within the volume of the material might induce ionic motion or molecular dipoles. The resistance of these induced motions causes losses which will cause attenuation in the electric field and volumetric heating of the material [65]. In addition, increasing the temperature increases the kinetic energy of the dipoles, making it easier for them to respond to the oscillating field and shifting the absorption curves to higher frequencies.
Because water is a good absorber at 2.45 GHz, most common MW furnaces used for domestic, industrial and scientific applications operate at this frequency [66]. The absorption of the MW energy within the material depends on the incident MW frequency, the dielectric constant of the material, the dielectric loss of the material, and the distribution of the electric field within the material [67]. Fortunately, absorption of poorly absorbing materials also can be improved by increasing their temperatures. This phenomenon has led to the development of hybrid MW heating, where the materials are heated initially using conventional methods [57]. This hybrid method can yield more uniform temperature distributions than those resulting from stand-alone MW or conventional processing methods. This uniformity is the result of MW volumetric heating and minimized heat losses. Hybrid heating can be achieved either by using an independent heat source, such as a gas or electric furnace in combination with MW, or
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
through the use of an external susceptor that couples with the MW. In the latter, the material is exposed simultaneously to MW energy and radiant conventional heat produced by the susceptor. MW hybrid sintering of HA ceramics has been studied in a 500 W MW oven using ZrO2 cylinder susceptor during the MW heating [113]. The study showed that MW hybrid sintering of HA was not only highly efficient in saving time and energy, but can also improve the microstructure and thus enhance mechanical strength of the HA ceramics. While MW energy alone will not be the answer to every technical barrier in materials processing, it can give us an alternative to the high energy consumption resistance heating techniques that are used now in industry. The question always arises as to the types of materials that are suitable for MW processing and how we can use this technology to improve the materials properties and performance.

sections.heading: 4.1. MW-assisted precipitation
sections.text:
The available literature indicated that Lerner et al. 1991, were the first to examine the effect of MW energy on the precipitation of CaP species. HA was successfully precipitated in aqueous solution within a domestic MW in less than one hour [8]. Results indicated that starting with a system of ions in solution processed by MW irradiation has directed the reaction toward the precipitation of crystals with recognizable apatite character. The degree of crystallinity was increased when the
ano-hydroxyapatite for bone substitutes, Ceramics International (2015), http:
M.N. Hassan et al. / Ceramics International ] (]]]]) ]]]–]]] 11
precipitation is subjected to more MW irradiation. Other workers precipitated HA rapidly using MW in air [68]. They also precipitated HA in pure nitrogen atmosphere to avoid formation of carbonated HA due to the contact with atmospheric CO2 at basic pH. HA (Ca/P ratio¼1.65) was found to be precipitated through effectively reduced kinetic barriers under MW irradiation [68]. MW-assisted synthesis of HA in aqueous solution was also reported to form a percent of tricalcium phosphate (TCP) with the produced HA [49]. This TCP percent could be reduced only after heat treatment at 1150 1C. Moreover, the formed HA further showed a reproducible growth and secretion patterns of cells when tested through a cell-culture method.
Adjusting the process parameters; such as aging time (up to 24 h), MW irradiation time and power (up to 1 h at 700 W), showed significant positive effects on the degree of crystallinity and thermal stability of pure HA synthesized via MW irradiation method compared to the conventional low heat coprecipitation method [69]. On the other hand, the synthesis of calcium deficient nHA (Ca/P ratio 1.5) by co-precipitation followed by MW irradiation in a domestic MW oven (15 min) showed a characteristic needle like morphology with size of 30 nm length and thermal stability only up to 600 1C [70]. Then, this prepared CDHA was further mixed with Glass Ionomer Cement in different compositions and proved to increase its compressive strength and resorption potential [71].
Other researchers further synthesized pure HA in Nano-plate like morphology by MW processing in a domestic MW oven in a short time (15 min), with improved crystallinity and reduced crystallization time [72]. This was prepared later as fluorinated nHA (MW synthesized) and showed slightly decreases in vitro dissolution with the increase in the fluoride ion substitution [73].
Irregular grain shape CDHA (with size about hundred Nanometers) was also precipitated through combining aging of the precipitate followed by MW processing [74]. This study produced similar conclusions in which the volume of the crystalline phase and Ca/P atomic ratio increase with the rise in MW exposure time [75,76]. Siddharthan et al. 2006, studied the influence of MW power on the crystallite size of pure nHA through applying a wide range of MW power on the
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
precipitation process. This revealed the selectivity in size and shape of nHA in relation to the variation of the power of MW irradiation [77]. This research group further precipitated nHA platelets with high temperature stability and biocompatibility via MW from calcium hydroxide derived from hen’s eggshells (calcium carbonates) [78]. More recently other investigators used MW directly to decompose eggshells powders directly and then to prepare nHA in the form of a bit larger Nanocrystals [20,79]. Mixed spherical and needle shaped nHA particles were obtained through MW-assisted precipitation reaction of calcium hydroxide and phosphoric acid. It was noted that increasing the pH decrease the yield of associated phases (αTCP and β-TCP powders) [80]. Hence, other effective chemical agents and physical parameters were further studied, combined with MW processing, to control the size and shape of the produced nHA during precipitation [39,50,81–85]. In this concern, highly agglomerated nHA spheres ( 35 nm) were precipitated with mean particle size remained fairly constant across all power settings of MW (20–100%). However, the mean particle size decreased when the ultrasound power increased during the synthesis process [39]. Well-crystallized and pure nHA (monodispersed Nano-rods) were prepared using MW in presence of Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), as the capping agent, in less than 3 min [82] (Fig. 6). In accordance, well-crystallized HA Nano-strips were synthesized using MW and Cetyl-Trimethyl-Ammonium bromide (CTAB) as a nucleation and growth controlling agent [85]. Further surfactant free, MW-assisted synthesis produced rod-like nHA that exhibited around 4 nm mesopores (Nanodots) on the surface, for successful controlled release of antibiotics when tested in vitro [86]. Nano-rod HA (Nanocomposites with alumina) were further prepared, and their biocompatibility were tested for proposed orthopedic applications [55]. The most recent MW-assisted nHA precipitation method successfully used concentrated body fluid to produce “biomimetic” amorphous carbonated nHA structure [87].

sections.heading: 4.2. Reflux-assisted MW-synthesis
sections.text:
Using a water condenser during a chemical reaction should have the advantage of carrying chemical reactions at elevated temperatures without drying the reaction vessel or increase the reaction pressure. Lopez-Macipe et al. 1998 studied the precipitation of nHA at atmospheric pressure and normal boiling temperature (using a water condenser) inside a MW irradiation setup (Prolabo Maxidigest). The formed HA particles were needle-like mesoporous with an average size 25–35 nm. However, this process seemed to be complex and should be assisted with the addition of citrate ions that act as Ca-complexing agent and constitute a template to provide minimum aggregation and smaller particles than in a bulk precipitation [84]. CDHA was also precipitated using the same setup and methodology through a lower Ca/P feed ratio of the reactants [88]. However, results showed that this reflux/MW-assisted method had low yield compared to conventional heating, and
ano-hydroxyapatite for bone substitutes, Ceramics International (2015), http:
M.N. Hassan et al. / Ceramics International ] (]]]]) ]]]–]]]12
the precipitation was mainly depending on temperature and did not depend on the pH value. In addition, both studies confirmed that the use of MW alone, instead of conventional heating did not favor a decrease in HA crystal size [84,88]. This is in contrast with other processing techniques, e.g. hydrothermal processing, in which the pH value and temperature were producing significant effect in altering the structure, size and morphology of nHA [89].
Liu et al., 2004 and 2005, precipitated flower-like HA Nanorods using a domestic MW setup modified with a refluxing system at various basic pH values, without the help of polymeric templates. Ca-Complexing reagent (EDTA) was used instead and was found to play important roles affecting the shape (nucleation and growth) of the synthesized HA Nano-structures [81,90]. The proposed mechanism of Ca ions release from the Ca-EDTA complex and its stability in relation to the pH and temperature was also illustrated.
Through the influence of EDTA, pure HA was precipitated in the form of uniform Nano-strips (50–100 nm) that showed a different morphology compared to the non EDTA (pure) HA [83]. Similarly, the process parameters (pH, feed molar ratio, and the chelating effect of EDTA) were modified to synthesize a bioactive nHA ceramic powder [17]. In this case, results have confirmed the production of a highly crystalline nHA powder with smaller size but in mixed (elliptical and rod-shape) morphologies.

sections.heading: 4.3. MW-assisted hydrothermal synthesis
sections.text:
In the recent years, the hydrothermal routes towards the synthesis of bioceramics (particularly nHA particles) have been reported to be advantageous, particularly since the other wet chemical methods (at lower temperatures) usually lead to irregular forms of HA powders and require complex process control. However, the conventional hydrothermal synthesis route is relatively complex and the reaction time is comparatively long [89,91]. Katsuki et al 1999, have totally converted gypsum into Nano-rod-HA crystals using the hydrothermal method. Compared to the conventional heating method that takes 8 h, the full conversion via the MW heating method was found to occur after only 5 min [92]. This research group was the first to prepare HA directly from gypsum waste through in situ crystallization via conventional heating in the late nineties [93]. Furthermore, they use MW field to accelerate the hydrothermal (liquid-state) method of needle-like HA crystal synthesis from an initial mixture of gypsum (calcium sulfate dihydrate) and diammonium hydrogen phosphate at 195 1C, with much faster kinetics [18]. The previous experiments were further repeated with longer time intervals in MW processing up to 3 h in the absence or presence of MgO as a sintering additive, which is also contained in bones thus cannot negatively influence the biological properties of HA. Samples with MgO (41%) showed higher HA proportions, converted in a high proportion from β-TCP after thermal treatment [62].
nHA powder was further synthesized by a MWhydrothermal method using a closed-vessel MW device at much higher temperature and pressure (4136.8 kPa and 300 1C
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
for 30 min) with purity determined as 99.995% [94]. It was noticed that the modification in the applied MW powers and mole ratio of Ca/P influenced the synthesis of calcium phosphate and its purity. Others used the hydrothermal method (MW Digestion System “MARS 5”) to explore nHA preparation under various temperature and time parameters, where the crystallinity degree and crystal size were found to increase with the increase of treatment temperature and/or time [76]. In addition, the morphology of the HA powder was transformed from small Nano-rod-like to large prism-like nature when increasing the internal temperature from 100 to 140 1C. In the recent few years, a progress has been made by Zhu’s research group in hydrothermal/solvothermal MW-assisted synthesis of Nano-structured CaP and nHA, using the modified MW oven (MDS-6, Sineo, China) with controlled measurement of pressure and temperature [50–54]. Qi et al. has prepared highly stable, porous, amorphous CaP Nano-spheres (average sphere size¼238 nm) via MW-assisted hydrothermal synthesis in acidic medium, using adenosine 5’-triphosphate disodium salt (ATP) as the phosphorus source [53]. The average size of the formed Nano-spheres were relatively uniform, and the porous structure (average pore size¼10 nm) showed high efficiency in anticancer drug (docetaxel) loading and release. Thus, the drug delivery system was very potent to damage tumor cells in vitro [53]. This study was further progressed to promote the MW-assisted preparation of crystalline nHA through using another organic phosphate source (Creatine phosphate disodium salt tetrahydrate) and elevating pH value (pH¼10). The produced nHA (Nano-sheets/Nanorods) were self-assembled in the form of Nano-porous hollow microspheres (around 1 mm in diameter) that exhibited good drug-loading and protein-adsorption capacities [54] (Fig. 7).

sections.heading: 4.4. MW-assisted solvothermal synthesis
sections.text:
A solvothermal process could be defined as the processing of precursor(s), in a closed reaction vessel, in the presence of a solvent at a temperature higher than its boiling temperature at normal pressure [95]. For the applications of drug delivery, Wang et al 2010 were the first to prepare nHA (Nano-sheets assembled in the form of hollow microspheres) with modified MW-solvothermal synthesis (polymer template) system using “MDS-6”. Polymer template concentrations were found to be important for the formation of the hollow structure. These HA hollow microspheres confirmed their efficiency in drug loading and release in vitro [51]. This process was modified later through a template free method, using sodium citrate dehydrate that played a role to produce hollow nHA microspheres with almost the same morphology and size [50] for a potential applications in drug delivery. Further highly crystalline and highly soluble Nano-CDHA was produced through solvothermal processing, nevertheless using high energy density field of MW radiation (5 W/mL) for only 90 s. The produced particles were of needle-like shape (5–20 nm). The cyto-compatibility test of the obtained material was conducted in a culture of human bone derived cells in both

the indirect test (using the material extract) and in direct contact [96].

sections.heading: 4.5. MW-assisted metathesis (Solvent free)
sections.text: The first example of metathesis (solvent free or solid state) reaction was performed in the presence of MW irradiation producing spherical nHA from calcium chloride and sodium phosphate in solid phases and was reported by Parhi et al, 2004 where the particles were obtained in an irregular diameter distribution [19]. MW heating as a processing method to synthesize HA by one-step solid-state reaction at room temperature was further introduced to obtain Nano-rods HA [43]. In addition, results showed that continuous MW heating led to large sized HA Nano-rods when compared with the interval heating method. Spherical nHA particles (CDHA, 50 nm and Ca/P¼1.5) were also prepared through a mechanically-activated solid state reaction in a domestic MW for only 4 min, starting with stoichiometric molar feed ratio of calcium and phosphorous precursors [97].

sections.heading: 4.6. MW-assisted combustion synthesis
sections.text:
Jalota et al. 2004, produced various CaP pure phases (HA single phase, TCP single phase, and BCP “HA-TCP”) using "combustion (auto ignition) synthesis/Molten salt” hybrid method in a domestic MW device. This hybrid procedure represented the philosophy of synergistic processing, and the Nano-whiskers (powders) produced in this study were chemically similar to human bones (Na- and carbonate-containing) [98]. Further in vitro characterization of the produced Nano-
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
whiskers revealed an increased number of cells (mouse osteoblast cells) attached on the whisker compacts containing HA phase than other β-TCP and biphasic HA-TCP [99]. Further studies have used this method to dope nHA with europium, to be used with sufficient fluorescence emission intensity for bio-imaging applications [100].

sections.heading: 4.7. Ultrasonic-assisted MW synthesis
sections.text:
In the last few years, ultrasonic-assisted materials synthesis became popular to control some of the physical properties during the reaction [39]. Poinern et al 2011, prepared nHA via a wet precipitation method under ultrasonic irradiation using ammonium hydroxide as the precipitator. The study investigated the influence of the thermal treatment to produce ultrafine nHA powders using conventional furnace compared to MW-based technique. The results demonstrated that both thermal techniques (assisted with ultrasonic radiation) effectively produced ultrafine powders with similar crystalline structure, morphology and particle sizes [39]. Others suggested the sonochemistry-assisted MW process to synthesize carbonated HA (CHA) with high efficiency [101]. CHA Nanopowders that were synthesized through this process were evaluated against the conventional precipitation method. The outcomes showed that the ultrasonic-assisted MW process significantly increased the synthetic efficiency and obtained high yield of well-crystallized Nano-powders in a very short time. Moreover, the specific surface area, dispersibility and the crystallization process of the obtained product were improved with the increase of ultrasonic and MW power and reaction time.
ano-hydroxyapatite for bone substitutes, Ceramics International (2015), http:
M.N. Hassan et al. / Ceramics International ] (]]]]) ]]]–]]]14
This ultrasonic-assisted MW experiment was repeated with the same conditions to produce mesoporous nHA [102] without any templates in which the Ca and P precursors were precooled before mixing and heating. A well-crystallized nHA (carbonated) was formed with obvious mesoporous structure (average pore size of 2–3 nm) at mild temperatures (50–90 1C) that were controlled automatically with a cycle condensing system. The major role for the formation of mesopores was pointed to MW. MW energy produce clearer and much more mesopores in nHA (Fig. 8).

sections.heading: 5.1. HA precipitation in normal reaction conditions
sections.text:
The kinetics of pure HA precipitation via conventional methods [9,103] and the effect of the reaction parameters in normal conditions were illustrated in various studies [89,103]. Briefly, stoichiometric HA (Ca/P¼1.67) could be obtained only through an ionic reaction between Ca and P precursors at basic pH or/and elevated temperatures (Z100 1C), even if the feed Ca/P ratio is not optimum. Moreover, elevated temperatures could compensate for the precipitation of HA in acidic pH media, and the vice versa. However, in case of acidic pH at elevated temperatures, HA could be normally precipitated in complicated (mixed) morphologies. In addition, when precipitating HA at basic pH and relatively low temperatures (less than 70 1C), the obtained HA is calcium deficient (Ca/ P41.67).
In general, the size and morphology of the precipitated HA are influenced by the pH, temperature and holding time of the reaction. A controlled morphology obtained via isotropic crystal growth (in the form of Nano-rods) could be usually precipitated at basic pH and elevated temperatures. On the other hand, smaller particle sizes could be obtained at higher pH and lower temperatures. In addition, longer holding times at elevated temperatures was found to increase the particle size and modify its shape, while the holding time at lower
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
temperatures did not affect the size of the obtained HA [9,89,103].

sections.heading: 5.2. HA precipitation in MW conditions
sections.text:
In the MW synthesis of nHA, it is widely accepted that MW heating reduces the kinetic barriers of the normal HA ionic synthesis reaction [8,68]. Thus, it was previously thought that the application of MW on some chemical reactions could induce non-thermal effects that lead to advanced results [104,105]. However, some other studies where MW and conventionally heated reactions were done and concluded that both reaction kinetics do not differ significantly, providing that the reacting solutions are thermally homogenous and the reaction temperatures are well measured and known [106– 108]. It was assumed that the observed rate enhancements was originating from a purely thermal/kinetic effect, induced by the high reaction temperatures of the MW-irradiated polar materials [64]. Further studies are still needed and of great interest to clear this controversy. Many studies have illustrated the dynamics of HA precipitation via amorphous calcium phosphates (ACP) precipitation in basic buffered solution (pHZ10) followed by the need for further heat treatment to render significantly higher degree of crystallization [8,49]. However, MW irradiation was found to induce a direct precipitation to nHA without the stage of converting the ACP phase into HA [82]. The initial step for HA formation is the activation of Caþ2 ions for the reaction by loosening out the surrounding hydration molecules from their complexes (Fig. 9) [8,68,77,85,109]. In the majority of reactions, Ca precursors are normally in the form of a hydrated complex (e.g. di or tetra hydrated Ca salts or Ca-hydroxide) or in the form of anhydrous salts of ions capable to form hydration spheres in water solutions. Thus, while the intense interaction of bound water is due to the absorption of MW energy, bound water is eliminated and Caþ2 ions are locally “bared”. This consequently triggers a fast ionic interaction involving Caþ2, OH and PO 24 ions – unless interrupted – resulting in the
ltrasound-assisted MW method at different reaction temperatures (a) 10 1C, ticed at (b) and became clearer at (c). Adapted from Liang et al. 2013 [102].

precipitation of the most thermodynamic stable structure which is HA [109]. However, the absorption of radiation by free water at this frequency was found to be minimal [8]. The highly basic pH will ensure favorable HA precipitation [79,98,110] but the morphology of the synthesized nHA could be affected [81,90].
On the other hand, MW heating was found to interact with the crystalline water of the reagents in the solid state reactions to facilitate the diffusion of reagents, nucleation and growth of nHA. Meanwhile, nHA could not be obtained through conventional solid state heating at the same conditions [43, 97].

sections.heading: 5.3. Effect of MW conditions on the nano-HA physical properties
sections.text:
MW assisted synthesis of HA could produce various morphologies and sizes and phases according to the reaction parameters. Phase composition of the nHA synthesized
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
powders were easily controlled in basic pH (49) of the starting solution [79,80,98,100]. From the tabulated data in Table 2, it could be noticed that nHA was successfully precipitated in acidic pH but only at elevated temperatures (4100–300 1C) in MW-hydrothermal process [50–52]. This was found to promote self-assembly of nHA particles into hollow microspheres. The precipitation of HA in a slightly basic medium (pH¼7.4), produced calcium deficient particles with irregular grain shape and hundred Nano-meters in size [74]. Moreover, varying the pH values of the reactant solution led to a noticeable variation in morphology [90,111]. On the other hand, nHA in the form of Nano-needles were prepared from Calcium Hydroxide without the need to adjust the pH attributed to the strong alkalinity of the precursor (Calcium Hydroxide suspension) [112]. MW was found to be more efficient than conventional heating to obtain highly crystallized nHA in much less time [18,43,92]. However, other studies have confirmed that the use of MW instead of the conventional heating methods did not promote the decrease in HA crystal size [74–76,84,88]. Thus, it was found that nHA precipitation, its crystallinity and stoichiometry were dependent on the temperature and MW irradiation time regardless of the pH value [43,69,72,74,76,88]. Continuous MW heating led to a larger sized nHA than in the case of interval heating [43] in which continuous MW hybrid heating improves the sintering (larger size particles), that promotes the particle growth or/and agglomeration [113]. In most cases, the temperature of the reaction was not mentioned as there was no temperature measuring tools in domestic MW. However, from the available reported reaction temperature data, it is clear that the temperature also affects the morphology of obtained nHA. At short processing time, nHA was assembled in the form of Nano-rods, while assembled in the form of Nano-plates with longer holding time [50–52]. Thus, longer processing time led also to larger particle sizes [62]. The MW power was also found to be an effective factor that influences the nHA particle size [77,87] and crystallinity [97]. Keeping this in mind, several researchers further used other effective chemical [82] and physical agents (ultrasonic waves) [39] that were combined with MW processing to control the size and shape of the produced nHA during precipitation. Attempts were made to use polymeric templates to control the size and morphology of the prepared nHA assisted with MW [51,114]. On the other hand, citrate ions [50,84,85] and EDTA [79,81–83] were used as growth controlling agents to decrease the particle size and reduce aggregation of the produced particles giving a Nano-rods/strips morphology. Synthesized pure nHA assisted by MW and EDTA could directly produce various morphologies: Nano-rods [81,82,90,111], Nano-strips [83] or leaf like flakes [79]. However, in some cases, the higher order of crystalline pure HA could be only observed after sintering at high temperatures [83,111].

sections.heading: 6. MW synthesized BCP
sections.text:
The feasibility of in-situ formation of BCP (HA/β-TCP) ceramics using MW irradiation was indicated by Sampath Kumar et al. 2000. They synthesized carbonated HA (CHA) and BCP by the substitution of calcium hydroxide by calcium carbonate during the reaction with diammonium phosphate under MW irradiation [115]. Afterwards, the formation and characterization of BCP synthesized under MW irradiation consisting of HA and β-TCP in various ratios was reported [116]. Both reports confirmed the resorbable nature of the produced BCP samples in a phosphate buffer.
The authors of this article have recently reported the rapid conversion of sol–gel derived HA into β-TCP through domestic MW application [117]. On the contrary, MW was used to prepare nHA as a major phase through the hydrolysis of solidstate reacted α-TCP. The produced Nano-whiskers were obtained with enhanced morphology, Ca/P and in much shorter time in case of MW, however, a remaining minor phase of αTCP was still present [118]. This process of α-TCP conversion was further used for the preparation of HA/β-TCP composites producing the same morphology [119].

sections.heading: 7. Recent trends in MW-assisted biomaterials processing
sections.text:
MW assisted sintering have been used with 3D printing of interconnected macroporous TCP scaffolds for bone tissue engineering applications. The porous MW processed scaffolds showed better mechanical (compressive) strength over the conventionally processed scaffolds. This was attributed to the more radial shrinkage exhibited by the MW processed scaffolds, which in turn reduced pore size and total porosity. In vivo study of such scaffolds showed that both micro- and macrospores facilitated osteogenesis in a rat femur model,
Please cite this article as: M.N. Hassan, et al., Microwave-assisted preparation of N //dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ceramint.2015.11.044
however, the in vitro cell culture study using human osteoblast cells revealed an increase in cell density accompanied by the decrease in pore size in case of MW processing of scaffolds [120]. Other researchers have used MW assisted process recently to synthesize amorphous magnesium phosphate precursors in Nano-spherical forms that showed preliminary biocompatibility with osteoblast cells in vitro [121]. For rapid surface modification of biomaterials, MW assisted coating technology was successfully applied to uniformly coat a dense CDHA layer on titanium substrates [91] and magnesium alloy substrates [122] in a very short time, thus improving their biocompatibility, bioactivity and/or biodegradability. MW plasma-assisted technique was also used in other biomedical applications to grow a hard carbide surface coating on Co–Cr–Mo implant alloys that were used in artificial joints to increase their wear properties [123,124]. In addition, MW solved many limitations for polymeric biomaterials [125,126], including the preparation of chitosan [127] and ε-caprolactone [128] in much less time than the conventional reflux process that takes usually several hours or longer. Researchers have also studied the application of MW to prepare a decellularized tissue scaffold for tissue engineering applications. They succeeded to prepare decellularized soft tissues (tendon) and cartilage using MW assisted with a chemically detergent process. However, further optimization of the electromagnetic field in the oven is needed to improve the efficiency of tissue decellularization [129]. MW prepared modified nHA was also used in other environmental [130] and antimicrobial applications [86,131].

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and future prospective
sections.text:
Various methods for MW-assisted synthesis of nHA were extensively accomplished to investigate its effect on the
ano-hydroxyapatite for bone substitutes, Ceramics International (2015), http:
M.N. Hassan et al. / Ceramics International ] (]]]]) ]]]–]]] 17
produced HA Nano-crystals, including Ca/P ratio, particle size and shape, crystal structure, and biological properties. It was found that pH, temperature, pressure, MW power and duration are having a superior effect on the formed phase structure and morphology. Also, the feed molar ratio of Ca/P, the chelating effect of EDTA and the synergetic effect of ultrasound have proved to influence the morphology and size of the produced nHA. MW-assisted preparation of nHA was found to be significantly efficient and economic. MW-assisted methods have the advantages of selective and effective super heating due to the optional/changeable MW radiation frequency, holding time and power that lead to the extra fast reaction process. In addition, MW processing "sintering" of biomaterials could aid intra-operative processing and application of HA bone grafts which are considered for various applications to replace and repair bone tissues. Furthermore, working on further controversy and unexplored points such as the thermal versus the non-thermal effects in MW-assisted synthesis of nHA.

metadata.abstractText: Calcium phosphate-based biomaterials have been frequently used as bone substitutes and osteoconductive scaffolds due to their chemical similarity to the inorganic phase of bone. Hydroxyapatite (HA) is the most frequently used calcium phosphate-based biomaterials and it could be prepared from natural or synthesized sources via several processes. Nano-HA (nHA) particles were suggested to have superior bioresorbtion and close chemical and crystallographic structure to natural bone apatite. Currently, microwave-assisted (MW) processing of biomaterials, particularly bioceramics, has more appealing advantages than conventional heating methods. It works through an internally generated heat inside the materials molecules instead of originating external heating source and subsequent radiative transfer as in the conventional heating. Thus, MW synthesis of HA offers several benefits including rapid heating, shorter synthesis time, efficient energy transformation and throughout volume heating. The purpose of this review is to highlight the various methods and the paradigm shift of MW techniques to synthesize nHA in the past 25 years. Peer-reviewed journal publications (Scopus and Google Scholar indexed articles) in which titles and keywords combining “Microwave AND Nano-Hydroxyapatite” were collected from 1990 till May 2015. The discussions include the state-of-the-art and the role of reaction parameters on the HA structures, size, morphology and biocompatibility to be further used for bone regeneration applications. & 2015 Elsevier Ltd and Techna Group S.r.l.
